tit.e: Goshi (worship of two or more deities at a single shrine)
tit.cmt: Removed explanation as it is explained in cells F4 and F5

sen.j: 合祀（ごうし）とは、神道の用語で、ある神社の祭神を、別の神社で合わせて祀ること（寄宮）。
sen.e: "Goshi" is a Shinto term and it refers to enshrinement of a deity belonging to a Shinto shrine at another shrine together with that shrine's original deity (this is called yosemiya).
"Goshi" is a Shinto term that refers to the enshrinement of kami (deity, spirit) from one shrine at another shrine (this is called yosemiya).
"Goshi" is a Shinto term that refers to the enshrinement of kami (deity, spirit) from one shrine at another shrine (this is called yosemiya).

sen.j: または、一つの神社に複数の祭神が祀られている状態のこと（相殿）。
sen.e: This term also means enshrinement of two or more deities at one shrine (this is called aidono).
This term also means enshrinement of two or more kami at one shrine (this is called aidono).
This term also means enshrinement of two or more kami at one shrine (this is called aidono).

sen.j: 合祭（ごうさい、がふさい）とも言う。
sen.e: Goshi is also known as gosai or gafusai.

sen.j: 前者の合祀には、神社建築で祭神を一緒に祀る本殿合祀と、神社の境内に元の神社を移転し境内社とする境内合祀、離れた飛地境内に移転し境外社とする飛地境内合祀の3種類がある。
sen.e: The former goshi consists of three types of goshi: honden-goshi that all deities are enshrined together in one shrine building, keidai-goshi that a shrine is moved to another shrine's precinct as a keidai-sha (a shrine existing within a precinct of the main shrine), and tobichi-keidai goshi that a shrine is moved to a distant tobichi-keidai (a detached precinct) as a keigai-sha (a shrine existing outside of a precinct of the main shrine).

sen.j: 明治から大正にかけての神社合祀では多数の神社が合祀の末、廃社された。
sen.e: Many shrines were abolished after their deities were moved to other shrines during the Jinja-goshi (shrine mergers) in the Meiji and Taisho periods.
Many shrines were abolished after their kami were moved to other shrines as a result of the Jinja-goshi (shrine mergers) in the Meiji and Taisho periods.

sen.j: これら廃社された神社の中には、後に合祀されていた祭神を戻し（復祀）、再建されたものもある。
sen.e: Some of those abolished shrines were rebuilt by restoring their deities that had been enshrined at other shrines (this restoration is called fukushi).
Some of those abolished shrines were later rebuilt and the kami, which had been enshrined at other shrines, were returned (this restoration is called fukushi).
